content:
uhm solved as a 4th grade equation (nulling the derivative of the time function ), so O(1) solution
did I overshoot that ? :D

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solved it in C++.  Really fun problem, well done!

I am getting an answer 1 higher (5034943) for the last validator, looks like you have a precision problem.  The change below fixes it if you want to keep the same validator, but you are going to get complaints since code like your current solution will pass all test cases but fail when submitted.

import decimal
        to_beach = decimal.Decimal( (startx-beachx)*(startx-beachx) + (starty-beachy)*(starty-beachy) )**decimal.Decimal(.5) / speedland
        to_ball = decimal.Decimal( (ballx-beachx)*(ballx-beachx) + (bally-beachy)*(bally-beachy) )**decimal.Decimal(.5) / speedwater

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved, solved in Dart.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good that test cases have unambiguous integer answers. The puzzle also has a nice "flavor text" that brings some fun and creativity instead of just asking for the calculated result.
Interesting puzzle, waiting for republish and moderate

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

There is no test case for when the speed in water is more compared to the speed on land, it seems counterintuitive but consider that water and land are 2 different unknown mediums and it is not known where the speed will be more. To help fellow coders have a more holistic approach while coding, I think test case where the speed in water is more compared to land should be there.

Nice puzzle. Is any other than bisection good solution for it? I tried to deep into derivatives, to fix the fact that travel time function has only one minimum at interval (startx,ballx), but failed to find 4th degree equation solution in general case.

The test and validation values have been updated so that the correct answer can be achieved by either finding the best integer value or by finding the best float value and then rounding.  I feel this makes the challenge easier but still 'medium'.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good that test case require unambiguous integer answers.  The scenario in the description is very fitting for the problem as well as showing creativity.
The water speed in the tests has been updated to be equal to or less than the land speed.
I changed the hardness from easy to medium because a simple brute force of all integers from min(x) to max(x) won't finish in time.
ok got it
??????? ok i am new to this and i dont get what you are sayin
It should be doable with algebra using Snell's Law.  I meant to do this, but just didn't get down to it.  I'll take this as a reminder to write up that solution, thanks.

It is actually one of the constraints,

1 ≤ speed_water ≤ speed_land ≤ 1,000

Swimming in water is slower than running on land, so I'd like to keep it that way.
Republished and ready for moderation
cool!  thanks for doing it in a different language
Thanks Westicles!  I've updated the last validation test so that the above change to my code will return the correct answer.
That's great!  It is supposed to be solvable like that, but tbh I was just too lazy to do it.  Glad to see it is possible and fits the validation tests
if you're bad at algebra (like me) you can also use ternary search
Sorry for the long delay.  Yes, give that a try

I will expand on my comment below.  Feel free to ask for further clarification if you still have questions.
Context: My original comment was talking about the quality of the contributed puzzle.
1) "Good that test case require unambiguous integer answers."  Automated tests are different than human judgement in that they do not provide feedback on the quality of the solution, only pass/fail.  As such they should be clear and avoid frustrating "near miss" answers.  Integer answers are clear like that.  The problem with floating point is that rounding errors can make a solution that works in one language fail in another. You can google more on the perils of floating point comparisons.
2) "The scenario in the description is very fitting for the problem as well as showing creativity."  The puzzle scenario provides a justification for the calculation needed to solve the test cases.  That makes the scenario "fitting" rather than "arbitrary" or "bizarre".  The puzzle also has a nice "flavor text" that brings some fun and creativity instead of just asking for the calculated result. I found it to be pleasant.
